_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - Overhill Farms, Inc.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Overhill Farms has established a Risk Management Plan according to EPA's regulations (40 CFR Part 68)  for the Refrigeration System at its Vernon facility to enhance its already existing safety programs.  Overhill Farms is extremely cautious in the handling of all chemicals and is very diligent about safety for its employees and its communities.  Overhill Farms staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to provide safeguards.  The Refrigeration System, that contains the regulated substance anhydrous ammonia, is used for freezer operation and chilling water.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Overhill Farms has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program to manage the safety aspects of the Refrigeration System.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by industry sources.  In addition to the Management Programs, there are ammonia detectors situated in all those compartments where ammonia is present.



Overhill Farms has an emergency response plan in effect to handle potential emergency situation at this facility.  This plan is designed to meet the following objectives:



1.) To save lives.

2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.) To protect the environment.

4.) To minimize property damage.



Key elements of the Emergency Response Plan include a discussion of the overall approach elected by Overhill Farms for implementation at the facility, key phone numbers and conctact points, vicinity and evacuation maps, plans for evacuation, fire, injury, threats and civil disorder, earthquake, potential imminent danger to personnel, chemical spill, and ammonia health hazards.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The Refrigeration System at the Overhill Farms is a two-stage system comprised of compressors, evaporative con

densers, a high-pressure receiver, evaporators, a glycol heater, water chillers, heat exchangers, an intercooler, a thermosyphon vessel, two recirculators, and an accumulator.



The Refrigeration System at Overhill Farms provides the cooling medium for several spiral freezers, holding freezers, a 34oF Cooler, shipping and receiving docks, one glycol heater, water chillers, and heat exchangers.  The Refrigeration Sytem contains anhydrous ammonia that continuously circulates through the system.  Vaporization of ammonia at different points of the system provides the needing cooling effect.



Hazard Assessment Summary



Worst-Case Release Result Summary



Scenario Description:  it is assumed that liquid ammonia is released from the largest vessel, that is, the High Pressure Receiver.  Per the instructions of the regulation, the release is postulated to occur in 10 minutes.  Since the vessel is located outside of a building, passive mitigation measures were not incorporated into the calculations.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used as specified in the regulation.  The reference table included in the EPA's RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm.  The result shows that offsite areas may be affected.



Alternative Release Result Summary



Two alternative release scenarios were considered.  Scenario Description: ALT-1:  A 1/4 inch equivalent diameter opening on a liquid pipe, which is 15 feet above the ground, at 150 psig pressure and remains under pressure until the charge of the system is emptied.  ALT-2:  Same as ALT-1 except that the equivalent diameter is 1/2 inch.  The scenario models a leak from a valve packing or a pipe connection.  However, the selected opening diameter is very conservative given the typical opening s experienced in similar situations.  The meteorological conditions specified in the regulation for alternative scenarios were used.  The reference table included

in EPA's RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm.  The downwind distances for these scenarios are significantly less than that for the worst-case scenario.  However, in these cases also, offsite areas may be affected.



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Overhill Farms, Inc. has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program to manage the safety aspects of the Ammonia Refrigeration System. In addition, common industry standards, policies, andprocedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. This includes common practices

outlined by industry sources. In addition to the Management Programs, there are ammonia detectors situated in all those compartments where ammonia is present.



Five-Year Accident History



There have been no incidents where ammonia has been released to the atmosphere due to the operation of the Overhill Farms, Inc. Ammonia Refrigeration System in the past five years (November 2008 to November 2013).



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Several Process and management system improvements are being considered and implemented as a result of the technical studies performed in the development of the PSM/RMP Program. These improvements include physical and administrative changes related to operation of the Ammonia Refrigeration System.
